Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Methods for Spatially Correlated Hierarchical Functional Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project is to create new statistical models and methods for the analysis of hierarchical functional data. In particular the investigator proposes a novel methodological framework for fast and robust inferential tools when the true data generating process accounts for complex correlation mechanisms that mimic and represent true biological structures. The project has the following aims. (a). To develop a new methodological framework for the analysis of hierarchical univariate functional data when the functions at the lowest level of hierarchy are correlated. Understanding and quantifying the dependence structure between these functions is of scientific importance. (b). To extend the developed methodology to the analysis of multivariate functional data. (c). To propose new inferential methods for group means and differences between group means when functional data have a natural hierarchical and spatial structure.

Modern research data have become increasingly complex, raising non-traditional modeling and inferential challenges. In particular, advancements in technology and computation have made recording and processing of functional data possible. An increasing number of scientific experiments record hierarchical functional data with complex dependence structures. Although the proposed research was motivated by data from a colon cancer experimental study, correlated functional data arise in many areas of research. The statistical methods developed in this proposal are timely and important and will be relevant to many new data sets, where the object of inference are functions or images that remain dependent even after conditioning on the subject on which they are measured. Such data are collected in engineering and climate modeling among others. In contrast with other published methods, the methodology proposed here is computationally efficient and it scales well to moderate and large data sets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research funded by this grant contributed to the advancement of statistical methodology for the analysis of hierarchical functional data. Our methods were inspired by and applied to data obtained from a state-of-the-art colon carcinogenesis scientific experiment. Briefly, 12 rats were divided into four diet groups (corn or fish oil with or without butyrate supplement) and were assayed 24 hours after carcinogen exposure. Outcomes such as the protein concentration level, p27 (tumor suppressor gene) or apoptosis (programmed cell death), are measured for all cells within 20 colonic crypts situated at various locations across the colon tissue. Figure 1 shows the p27 profiles on log scale for all crypts. In contrast with other published methods, the methodology we proposed is computationally efficient and it scales well to moderate and large data sets.

There are three main components to this research: 1) the development of a new methodological framework for the analysis of hierarchical univariate functional data when the functions at the lowest level of hierarchy may be correlated; 2) the extension of the procedure to multivariate functional data; and 3) the development of inferential methods for group means and differences between group means when functional data have a natural hierarchical and spatial structure.

We first focused on estimation of the mean p27 profiles in each diet group, by accounting for the complex dependence in the data; see Staicu et al. (2010). Figure 2 shows how the faulty assumption of independence (two left plots are obtained by employing such assumption) causes misleading results (compare with the rightmost plot obtained by accounting for the dependence with our method). The difference is visually striking: the spread of the estimated mean functions is visibly larger, and moreover the estimates of the group mean functions are affected differently, which may lead to different inferences. In Serban et al. (2013) we extended these ideas to binary outcomes; for the colon carcinogenesis experiment, it allows us to estimate the probability of apoptosis for cells at different ages to study the effect of various diets on the progression of colon cancer. An insufficient amount of apoptosis results in uncontrolled cell proliferation, the leading cause of cancer.

Next we proposed a modeling framework for the joint analysis of multiple real-valued functional responses nested within a hierarchy where the functions are observed on a spatial (or temporal) grid and are assumed to exhibit spatial (serial) auto- and cross-correlations; see Tidemann-Miller et al. (2014). These methods allowed us to study the joint behavior of p27 and apoptosis for gaining a better understanding of the dynamics of their cross-dependence. Figure 3 provides insights into the functional cross-dependence for the bottom half of the crypt; our analysis shows indication of negative weak cross-correlation between p27 and apoptosis in this part of the crypt.

Finally we proposed statistical frameworks for testing hypotheses about the structure of the mean function of complex functional processes: Staicu et al. (2014b) considered an L2 -norm-based global testing procedure and discussed two bootstrap-based alternatives, and Staicu et al. (2014a) introduced pseudo-likelihood based tests.

There are three major sources of novelty in this proposal. First, the functions at the lowest level of hierarchy are not independent; understanding and quantifying their dependence structure was of primary importance. New methodological and theoretical developments were proposed to address these new types of data.
